text: Can I run a Python script as a service (in Windows)?
I am sketching the architecture for a set of programs that share various interrelated objects stored in a database.
I want one of the programs to act as a service which provides a higher level interface for operations on these objects, and the other programs to access the objects through that service.
I am currently aiming for Python and the Django framework as the technologies to implement that service with.
I'm pretty sure I figure how to daemonize the Python program in Linux.
However, it is an optional spec item that the system should support Windows.
I have little experience with Windows programming and no experience at all with Windows services.
Can I run Python programs as a Windows service (i. e. run it automatically without user login)?
I won't necessarily have to implement this part, but I need a rough idea how it would be done in order to decide whether to design along these lines.
Edit: Thanks for all the answers so far, they are quite comprehensive.
I would like to know one more thing:How is Windows aware of my service?
Can I manage it with the native Windows utilities?Basically, what is the equivalent of putting a start/stop script in /etc/init.d?
